Today, former PM Tony Blair has called on the Government to introduce vaccine passports now or  risk further lockdowns. 

@PaulNuki and @sneweyy spoke to leading experts and look at three options for how things might pan out over the next six months 👇

An ugly scenario - one in which a hard lockdown was forced by factors beyond our control - is much less likely but could be caused by a new vaccine-evading variant of Covid.

A recent Sage paper described this as a  reasonable possibility , meaning it was between 40-50 percent  probable.

Alastair McLellan, editor of the Health Service Journal, is not optimistic. Asked for his good, bad or ugly prediction:

 Its either going to be bad or very ugly. The obvious thing to say is that its bad right now.  The system is already very overstretched.

What does the bad outcome look like?

Experts say a bad outcome will essentially be what the UK has seen twice before.

Cases rise again, followed by growth in hospitalisations and deaths. Masks, vaccine passports and stronger communications are introduced but to no avail.

The best case scenario 👇

Things continue largely as they are, with everything open and people - slowly but surely - returning to life as normal.

Andrew Lilico, a proponent of this view, believes that  in England at least, the coronavirus epidemic is now de facto at an end .

The only real question we Britons are asking at the moment is this: will there be another lockdown this winter?

We spoke to many of the country’s leading experts. Here are their thoughts on the months ahead.

⚡️A new study reveals that thousands of women experienced irregularities after their jab – yet the medical establishment seems disinterested

This research comes too late for many of us, but it is still hugely welcome. Unlike the medical gaslighting approach, it may actually convince some vaccine hesitant women to get their jab 

Read more from @CCriadoPerez ⤵️

This type of groupthink may also have contributed to the sidelining of women’s specific health issues throughout the pandemic.

🔴Multiple women reported being unable to access contraceptive coils or injections — or even to have out-of-date ones removed

More broadly, being disbelieved and dismissed by the medical establishment is nothing new for women 

🗣️ Women are simply not considered to be reliable narrators of their own bodies  writes @CCriadoPerez

Part of the rush to dismiss women on the basis of little to no evidence comes – no doubt – from a well-meaning, but ultimately misguided effort to reduce vaccine hesitancy in young women, although if anything will drive hesitancy it is exactly this kind of medical gaslighting
In fact, there are several biologically plausible mechanisms, but we lack the research to prove the point either way  says @CCriadoPerez

As far back as 1913, a doctor was investigating the potential menstrual impact of typhoid vaccines. 

But despite this, many doctors and researchers continue to dispute that there is any biologically plausible mechanism by which the vaccines could affect the menstrual cycle
When women first started reporting menstrual cycle irregularities following the vaccine, the lack of data on this issue led doctors to dismiss their concerns

As with most clinical studies, the Covid vaccine trials didnt investigate menstrual cycle effects – in fact, in many trials women are excluded because of potential cycle effects.

 Perhaps we should be grateful...that women were included at all  says @CCriadoPerez
But until this study, there has been little on offer, highlighting how little anyone has thought to consider the chance of a connection

This study is not the first we’ve heard of period disruption being linked to the jab. 

💉Ever since the vaccine roll-out began women have been all over social media, talking about how the vaccine seemed to have an impact on their menstrual cycle

Dr Victoria Male, a lecturer in reproductive immunology, who led the study, said that all the main vaccines - Pfizer, Moderna, AZ Oxford - were involved, but there has been no suggestion of a long-term impact on fertility

🇨🇱The team studied data from the Atacama Large Millimetre/submillimetre Array (Alma) telescope in Chile.

🔭Each molecule emits light at distinctly different wavelengths, producing a unique spectral  fingerprint  which can be picked up by telescopes

❌Sugars 
❌Amino acids 
❌Ribonucleic acid

❓Who will be offered a booster first?

Similarly to the original vaccine campaign, those in the first cohort of the JCVI’s priority list will be offered a booster first. 

This includes those living in residential care homes for older adults and staff working in those homes

Mr Bidens remarks came as he met Nato, G7 and European leaders at a series of emergency summits in Brussels. They discussed what to do if Putin, whose forces are suffering unrelenting daily casualties, decided to unleash weapons of mass destruction
Biden added:  We would respond. We would respond if he uses it [chemical weapons]. The nature of the response would depend on the nature of the use.
Asked whether a Kremlin-orchestrated chemical attack would trigger a military response, the US president said:  It would trigger a response in kind

Joe Biden on Thursday night declared that Nato would respond  in kind  if Vladimir Putin resorted to using chemical weapons against Ukraine.

📱Were attached to our handsets for an average of 4.8 hours a day - so if you cant cut down, use that time well

📱 All we need to do is wake up to what’s happening and then it’s relatively straightforward to take control  says Robertson 

Heres what to do if you’re addicted to your phone 👇

While specific apps aren’t inherently good or bad, Robertson argues the context in which we use them can be. 

✅Finding activities we can do with other people? Good. 

❌Scrolling through other people’s status updates to compare their lives with yours? Arguably not so good.

Robertson calls it  curating  your device: working out what interrupts us and making choices about how and when it does. 

🧠The conscious or mindful phone user will turn off notifications and and engage at a time of their choosing, rather than being at the mercy of their apps

That’s not to say we can offset an hour of Instagram with a brain-training online Sudoku puzzle. 

⏰The goal, rather, is to be conscious of what you’re using and how, so that you’re in control, Robertson suggests

However, Andy Robertson, technology expert, argues it’s not so much about what we’re using our phones for as how we’re using them. 

 It’s really about a healthy balance and variety,  he says. 

📱 A sign of unhealthy use is doing the same thing all day.

🧠Just as we know how the technology hooks us, we also know some of the harms excessive phone use can cause.

Too much screen time has been linked to everything from depression, anxiety and sleep problems to cognitive changes in the brain

📱If you’ve already broken your New Year’s resolution to spend less time glued to your phone screen, you’re far from alone

But is all phone use equally ill-advised, or are there ways we can limit the damage and enjoy good quality screen time?

⚡️Myth buster: It’s Freedom Day – but will our fear ever lift?

The world has changed forever.

Will our fear of Covid ever end?

ANSWER: 2/3

National Rail journeys are less than two-thirds of what they were; the Tube 59 per cent; buses 75 per cent

Domestic travel still hasnt returned to pre-pandemic levels.

How many fewer National Rail journeys are there now?

ANSWER: 3

Adults on average still only have three face-to-face  contacts  per day, down from about 10 or 11 pre-pandemic

❓Before the pandemic adults had between 10-11 different face-to-face contacts each day.

How many do we have now?

ANSWER: 39 percent  

Some 39 per cent of Britons say they are scared of catching Covid. 

Almost half of us still avoid crowded public places, and three-quarters of Britons think that the Government is moving too fast
❓How many of us say we are still scared of catching Covid?

It was Freedom Day this week – but will our fear ever lift?

Thursday marked the day where the Government scrapped remaining Covid restrictions, but the data shows that Britain is far from back to normal.

@MarkGaleotti assesses the leaders 20 years in power

❌No one is willing to tell him that he has time and again misjudged the Ukrainian people and that his pressure does no more than drive them further away

Read the full story 👇

✍️Mistrustful and awkward, with few friends and confidants, he finds himself surrounded by a claque of yes-men and opportunists…

…who have learned that the safest thing to do is to flatter his prejudices and applaud his whims

🇷🇺This is a man who grew up running with street gangs in the post-war ruins of Leningrad.

And who was so eager to join the KGB – the biggest gang in town – that he tried to apply when he was still a schoolboy

➡️In part, this is a matter of trust. 

In a system without true rule of law, it would mean handing power over his and his friends’ fates and fortunes to a successor. 

Putin is not a man to trust easily, at the best of times

🔴After 20 years in power, he is less willing than ever to be disagreed with and appears to believe himself indispensable. 

He may occasionally flirt with the idea of stepping down, but that seems to be becoming less, not more likely over time

No wonder he seems more isolated, even paranoid, writes Mark Galeotti.

✍️Even without Covid, long-serving leaders don’t age well, and it is becoming increasingly clear that – like so many autocrats – Putin is becoming a caricature of himself
➡️Beyond a relative handful of his closest aides and friends, everyone has become a two-dimensional figure on a screen to him, his country a foreign land experienced through the TV news

❌For the best part of two years, Putin has been kept in a biosecurity bubble of such severity that people scheduled to meet him spend a fortnight in guarded isolation.

And even then have to pass through a tunnel fogged with disinfectant and bathed in ultraviolet light

For James Brown, the merits of this digital age are uncertain.
 
🗣️  We’ve come a long way since the days I had to scrabble around in search of stamps, but I’m not sure it’s in the right direction

❓ What does all this change mean for the older generation?
 
 The latest figures from Ofcom show only 55 per cent of over-65s use a smartphone, while digital poverty’ is a barrier facing around 11.3 million people across the UK

💉 Even digital vaccination certificates are preferred to physical records:
 
 I was initially refused entry to the Olympic Stadium in Stratford for a Leeds v West Ham game because I had naively brought along my NHS vaccination record card

🏦  I don’t know where my nearest actual bank is. Authentication checks are constantly sent to our phones to access work accounts, financial services and more 
 
🧳Since Covid,  passenger locator information and boarding cards all get filed away to a neat little digital wallet

📳 Now, it seems that smartphones are needed for everything: from online banking to two-factor authentication.
 
⌛️  On average, we pick up our phones 58 times a day, spending three hours and 15 minutes on them

But things took a turn for the worst when coin parking machines were replaced by apps.
 
🚗  I could no longer park my car legally without a smartphone. Either the car had to go, or my Nokia did

🙏 At first, ditching his smartphone was a  total godsend .

🌤️ My mind was calmer, my focus better, my phone costs far cheaper. I never panicked about my phone being about to die because, without all the apps, the battery never ran down

📵 Now that smartphones have become a near-essential part of life, is it possible to get on with just an old-fashioned Nokia?
 
🤷‍♂️ When James Brown tried this in 2016, it did not go well

❌ However, postcard-writing might be a thing of the past, with Royal Mail announcing moves to  connect the physical letter with the digital world .

🤳 Barcodes will be added to stamps so that recipients can scan them with their phones and access additional content
When my mum died a couple of years later I unpinned each of the postcards on her wall one by one, amazed at how many I’d sent

Brown describes the  personal ritual  that used to come with communicating with loved ones:
 
📮  Back in the pre-digital age, the simplest way to stay in touch with my mum back in Leeds was to send postcards

📱 For many, smartphones have become an essential part of daily life.
 
❓ So how did it go when our columnist, James Brown, tried ditching his?

⚡️ Is Covid really more deadly than the flu?

🦠It is likely now, that even with millions of Covid cases in December and January, excess winter mortality this year will not even approach a bad flu year - let alone the levels we have seen in previous waves

🔓This article is currently free to read

The infection fatality rate  - the number of deaths for all infections, not just positive cases - tells a similar picture. 

➡️Prof Paul Hunter, of the University of East Anglia, estimates it to be around 0.06 percent

📉Latest case fatality rates in England in the seven days up to January 26 are now just 0.14 percent  - one death in 714 positive cases…

…having fallen further since hundreds of thousands of reinfections were added to the case data

However, the situation has changed dramatically in the last few weeks. 

🔻The millions of cases sparked by the omicron wave have translated into relatively few deaths, bringing an important change in the deadliness of Covid

🔺It was previously much worse. In May 2020, the Covid case fatality rate peaked as high as 15 percent  - one death in six cases.

But it is fair to say that throughout the pandemic coronavirus has been far deadlier than flu

In comparison, the death rate for flu sits somewhere between 0.1 and 0.2 percent .

➡️ Or between one death in 1,000 and one death in 500

📈Before the vaccine roll-out and omicron surge, the answer was undoubtedly:  yes .

Even at the end of December, the rolling seven-day Case Fatality Rate for coronavirus was about 0.3 percent  or one death in 333 cases, based on a 21-day lag between testing and death

🦠It is a question that has plagued the pandemic, sparking furious debate over Britain’s dinner tables. 

Is coronavirus really any more deadly than flu?

🍜 Some good swaps for your favourite supermarket grabs might include tofu, homemade pasta sauce, plain yoghurt, and clear soups

🧐 This trick isn’t fail-safe, as many manufacturers are now focusing on  cleaning up  their labels.
 
🌽 This involves giving additives names that consumers might mistake for being all-natural, like  modified cornflour  instead of  modified starch

❓ So, how does one distinguish ultra-processed foods from the good stuff?
 
🏷️ One tip is to check the ingredients label – if you don’t recognise most of the ingredients, you may want to steer clear
🥫 However, not all processed foods are a lost cause. Baked beans are naturally vegan, and if you find a low-salt and low-sugar option, the fibre and protein dish out a great deal of nutrition
🏃 The problem may lie in many working adults being  time-poor , leading them to reach for whichever foods are most convenient at the supermarket

🧈 Processed foods branded as healthy are often high in sugar, refined carbohydrates, or fat.
 
⏲️ All processed foods have ingredients that have been manipulated to lead to a longer shelf life

💡 But making healthy choices is more complicated than simply avoiding processed foods.

Some supposedly healthy options like higher-protein snacks, vegan meat substitutes, and low-fat dairy products all run the risk of having lower nutritional value

🍬 Today, the most dominant threat to our nutrition is ultra-processed food: the items that come in brightly coloured, convenient packaging for a low price.

Despite the allure, there’s a reason why it’s so hard to stop reaching for that bag of crisps – they are highly addictive

🥦 With 2022 in full swing, many are trying to make good on their resolutions to eat healthier.
 
❓ We all know we shouldn’t eat greasy foods all day long, but which foods are actually healthy? The answer isn’t so clear-cut.

💡This means that even switching to a different role – or working for yourself – won’t protect you from burnout entirely.

That can be down to something that’s been dubbed the winner’s curse...

Read more👇

💻But it’s worth remembering that burnout isn’t always about the office you find yourself in.

It can be about the pressure that you put on yourself as well

Clinical psychologist Michaela Thomas says red flags that can indicate youre heading for burnout include:
 
🚩Forgetting things
🚩Being irritable
🚩Lacking motivation
🚩Feeling resentful, rushed and busy

Symptoms of burnout can manifest differently in different people.

Dr Samantha Madhosingh, a psychologist who now works as an executive coach, says one of the most common she sees is poor sleep habits 💤

Towards the end of last year, a survey by life company Juno confirmed this, finding that three-quarters of UK white-collar workers are considering quitting their jobs or changing their careers due to:

➡️Burnout
➡️Lack of work-life balance
➡️Toxic workplace environment

🗣️ Some teams have been running too hot for too long,  said Victoria Short, CEO of Randstad.

  The pandemic has changed how some people think about life, work, and what they want out of both. Covid has reminded them that life is too short

❌The Great Resignation has seen Brits resigning at a rate not seen since 2009.

Sanjay Raja, chief UK economist at Deutsche Bank, described it as  historically elevated levels of workers leaving the labour market entirely

🧑‍💻More and more of us are re-evaluating our relationship with work.

Trying to attain a better work-life balance is a key reason for people handing in their notice, but quitting might not be the answer to your burnout

🍻 How much is too much?

 Your chances of dying from an alcohol-related condition are one in 100 or less if you don’t drink more than 14 units a week - although that doesn’t mean that there’s no risk at all if you drink less than that

💊 Liver

Most alcohol that goes into your body is processed by your liver, and if it has to break down too much alcohol the health of your liver will suffer. 

Long term, drinking too much can lead to inflammation and scarring of the liver, and also liver cancer

❤️‍🩹 Heart

The risk of developing cardiovascular disease and some other heart conditions start to rise when you are consuming more than 14 units per week. 

Heavy drinking is also associated with high blood pressure and increased risk of stroke

🧠 Brain

The immediate effects of drinking on your brain can include slurred speech, slow reactions, impaired memory and blackouts. 

Long term, heavy drinking can cause brain damage and overuse of alcohol can also worsen the symptoms of many mental health problems

🧬 How alcohol affects the organs of your body.

Here is a brief rundown of the impact of booze on your body thanks to Alcohol Change UK 👇

❓ What should I be drinking?

Alcohol is alcohol. 

 There’s no evidence different types of alcohol affect the body in different ways,  says Dr Matt Parker, reader in neuroscience and psychopharmacology at the University of Portsmouth

🧠 What happens when alcohol hits your system?

 The majority is absorbed in the small intestine before passing to the liver - the alcohol then passes into your bloodstream and from there it can have an impact on the brain

Have you ever suffered with anxiety?

🧪  It is not an exact science, and everyone’s different - another reason why it’s so hard to make sense of or recognise .

 We know what to do when someone breaks a leg... but not how to help if they have a mental health issue

After a particularly bad night, she told her husband about her most intrusive thoughts.

The next day, she was referred to London’s oldest private psychiatric hospital - the Priory in Roehampton

💤  A bed advert reduced me to tears .

A phobia of going to bed and not sleeping began seeping into everything India did…

Outwardly, it didn’t add up,  says India  I enjoyed life. What happened? .

 Trying to sleep, no matter what I did, or thought, something primordial was flashing through my body, silently screaming

GAD is a long-term condition that causes you to feel anxious about a wide range of situations and issues.

💭 It’s characterised by at least six months of persistent, excessive and unrealistic worry about everyday things
🛏️ India had developed chronic insomnia, a phobia of going to bed - clinophobia’, PTSD and generalised anxiety disorder (GAD)
Stress and anxiety had percolated, fed off each other and imploded in a sort of slow-motion car crash over at least seven years
🏥 In 2019, the day before her 32nd birthday, India Sturgis became one of the 10 per cent of British people who suffer from a kind of disabling anxiety disorder

Anxiety robbed me of my sleep – and by 32, my life was a car crash’.

One woman’s all-consuming anxiety and her search for a cure. 👇

You might not want to be the only person in an open plan office doing a seated chair lunge ...

But Kerrie-Anne Bradley, the founder of Pilates At Your Desk, wants having a wiggle and a stretch to be culturally acceptable in the workplace

👣  The accumulation of lots of little changes will make an overall dramatic change which you can sustain long-term .

 Think of movements as snacks – 30 minutes of movement can be broken down into five-minute portions

❓ What about desk workers?

 Good posture isn’t about straightening up and rolling your shoulders back once. It’s about training yourself to move better naturally and consistently,  according to sports scientist Professor Greg Whyte OBE

Posture is affected by mood, and vice versa,  says physiotherapist and Pilates teacher Helen O’Leary.

 Movement and exercise, getting outside and socialising with others helps to reduce pain

Even the physically active are not immune to the so-called  posture pandemic  - Back pain afflicts 2.5 million people in the UK every day.

How can we avoid it? ⬇️

Prolonged sitting has been linked to:
◾️ Back pain
◾️ Diabetes
◾️ Cardiovascular disease 
◾️ Depression and anxiety

🧬  The poor health effects from too much sitting are separate from whether you are physically active or not,  explains Stuart Biddle, professor of physical activity and health at the University of Southern Queensland

❌ Adults of working age in the UK spend around nine and a half hours a day sitting down.

During the pandemic, our sedentary behaviour has been encouraged further by stay-at-home guidance

🪑 Why sitting down can kill you.

Sitting has been dubbed  the new smoking  as a sedentary lifestyle can come with a host of health risks.

🗣️It does feel like an endless struggle, and generations of children living by the beach will see this,’ says Joanna McFarlane who helps organise beach cleans with local children

🧹During beach cleans around North Queensferry, volunteers are given tweezers and a patch of ground the size of a large envelope to work on. 

Even after an hour of effort, that tiny fraction of beach will not be free of the pellets

🌊Nurdles persist in the water for decades so it is impossible to prove exactly where they have come from – as a result, rather than manufacturers or governments taking responsibility, it is often left to small bands of volunteers to fight back against the plastic tide

Beaches across the world are affected but those concentrated around industrial areas are particularly susceptible. 

🏴󠁧󠁢󠁳󠁣󠁴󠁿 North Queensferry, for example, is just a few miles from Grangemouth, Scotland’s largest container port

Nurdles can resemble fish eggs and as such they are being mistakenly gobbled up by more than 220 marine animals.

🔴When consumed by animals, the pellets cause false satiation’ whereby animals stop eating food because of the presence of nurdles in their stomachs

Cheap and designed to be as small as possible for ease of transportation, nurdles are susceptible to being lost at every point in the plastic supply chain: 

🚛Falling off the back of trucks 
🏭Falling on to factory floors
🌊Washing through drains out into the sea

🪥 Roughly speaking, it takes about 600 nurdles to make a toothbrush

🛍️ 175 for a small plastic bag 

🥣 350 to make a yogurt pot
When plastics are created they are extruded into long spaghetti-like strands, which are chopped up into nurdles and packed up, often into 25kg bags, then transported around the world
🌏Nurdles have existed since plastic was first mass-produced: the pellets form the basis for almost every plastic product on earth

💉Being fully vaccinated could reduce your risk of long Covid, according to ONS data released this week

Read the full list of factors that could raise your risk of long Covid here 👇

5⃣ Viral load 

The Cell article found that 1/3 of those with long Covid symptoms had a higher level of Covid RNA in the blood early in the infection – also known as  viral load .

🩺 This could explain why frontline workers are more likely to get long Covid, says Prof Banerjee

4⃣ The Epstein-Barr

The Epstein-Barr is a virus that infects most people when they’re young and then becomes dormant in their blood.

🩸The Cell journal article found a strong link between long Covid and patients who had traces of Epstein-Barr in their blood

3⃣ Asthma 

There is a strong link between asthma and long Covid.

 Asthma ticks several boxes,  says Professor Amitava Banerjee

 You’ve got an autoimmune angle, you’ve also got the inflammation as well, as well as the shortness of breath and respiratory disturbance

2⃣ Gender

Women are more likely to report long Covid symptoms at both four and 12 weeks after infection, according to ONS data. 

➡️After 12 weeks, 13.4 percent  of women were still reporting symptoms compared to 9.8 percent  of men

1⃣ Age

A September 2021 report by the Office of National Statistics showed that long Covid was most prevalent in adults who were 50 to 69 years old at both four weeks and 12 weeks after contracting the virus

📅While the study’s findings are significant, some experts have questioned the limited observational period of 2-3 months.

Nonetheless, research into what increases your risk of developing long Covid is growing all the time. 

Here are the major risk factors we know about 👇

The study took blood tests and nasal swabs from 209 patients who were infected with the coronavirus during 2020 and 2021. 

➡️Researchers found four potential factors that could increase the risk of contracting long Covid

🍿Titanic, Braveheart, Forrest Gump, The Silence of the Lambs, The English Patient, Shakespeare in Love, Schindler’s List

As with hand-held anti-tank munitions, researchers have been designing weapons to get above the vehicle in order to attack the less well-protected top of the turret

The Russian PTKM-1R top-attack mine was discovered on April 26.

This is the first time that the weapon has been seen deployed operationally
🔴This could kill the crew or cause the munitions inside to explode, or destroy the tank’s engines, rendering the vehicle inoperable

This explosively formed projectile travels so fast that it can penetrate 70mm of traditional steel tank armour.

➡️ It will rip through the thin plates on the top of the turret or the vehicle’s back decks

About two seconds later, at a height of about 30m, the Russian PTKM-1Rs radar and infrared seeker scan the ground to find the target.

A metal slug, usually made of copper, is then blasted at extreme speed towards the tank

🔴 Sensors on the mine listen for the sound of approaching vehicles and interpret vibrations through the ground to compare against a pre-programmed target list.

If the unit decides to attack, it expels a launching charge when the vehicle is 50m away

🇺🇦 A previously unseen anti-tank mine has been discovered in Ukraine.

The Russian PTKM-1R top-attack mine can leap into the air and attack the top of a turret.

In July 1999, he announced his retirement from the game after losing to Pat Rafter at Wimbledon.

🇩🇪 Fluent in English, he was dubbed Britain’s favourite German, though as he once joked about the nickname, he was  top of a short list

1⃣Boom Boom Becker

 If Boris had more than just charm and balls, he’d really be dangerous.

Boris believed he could bluff his way through it. The trouble is, when it comes to bluffing, Boris Becker is no champion

📅 In June 2017, Becker declared himself bankrupt over a £3.5 million unpaid loan to buy a villa in Mallorca.

But the court decided that, rather than genuinely attempting to repay his debt, Becker had deliberately hidden millions of pounds of assets before declaring bankruptcy

🔴 The procedures for an emergency:

People would make their way to the nearest shelter, leaving pets behind but bringing food and clothing. 

No alcohol would be allowed, and mobile reception is limited

During peacetime, the shelters have civilian functions, including:

📦 Storage rooms, 
🏸 Sports halls.
🏊 Swimming pools (which can be drained),

– but they must be only semi-permanent and able to be stripped away within 72 hours

Finland as a whole has shelter spaces for 4.4 million, in more than 54,000 separate locations.

👉 Since the Ukraine invasion there has been an uptick of public interest in defence strategy, with increasingly more people signing up for preparedness courses

Between the inside space and the outside world are two layers of cobalt-blue blast doors, each a foot thick. 

One is designed to stop a blast; the other to seal off the atmosphere
⚠️ In the event of an emergency, the arena would revert to being the Merihaka bomb shelter, a subterranean living quarters where up to 6,000 people could exist for weeks, or even months
Above ground, the only visible clue to its second identity is a small orange and blue triangle on the wall by the entrance that states:  VÄESTÖNSUOJA SKYDDSRUM , or  defence shelter

🇫🇮 With its brightly coloured slides, trampolines and tunnels, the soft play area near the centre of Helsinki, looks much like any other....

➡️ The difference is that it lies 25m below ground and is designed to withstand nuclear, biological and chemical attacks

⚡️ How privatising Channel 4 could backfire

However, mounting public backlash against a sale from politicians, industry and the public could further complicate matters.

Read the full analysis here 👇

📺A takeover by ITV or another broadcaster with an existing UK presence such as Sky is most likely, argues Barringer, because they would benefit from adding Channel 4’s viewers to their audiences, giving them greater appeal to advertisers

🖥️ Potential buyers could also seek to expand All4, its streaming service which has attracted large numbers of younger viewers and started offering  box set  programming to users long before most competitors
➡️ Channel 4 could emulate the ITV model, which over the years has shifted away from a focus on advertising income to television production

🗣️ Ministers believe that by going private, or being taken over by a bigger player, Channel 4 can raise cash through debt or equity and use those funds to expand its output and improve services.

What could happen then? 👇

👥All4, Channel 4’s free streaming service, has 24m registered users.

Netflix has almost 10 times that number of paying subscribers globally and an estimated 14m in the UK

❓ Why cant Channel 4 compete with Netflix?

The differences in resources are stark. Channel 4’s annual programming budget stands at about £660m, while Netflix spent $17bn (£13bn) last year

However, detractors warn that a for-profit Channel 4 may be forced to ditch the distinctive and edgy programming it is best known for.

🔴 They also question whether the broadcaster really can - or should - try to compete with America’s entertainment titans...

🎓 Where are the best schools in your local area?

Read the exclusive guide in full here ⤵️

📍 East Riding of Yorkshire, Beverley.

Average 🏠: £123,848

The market town of Beverley is in a different local authority area to Hull. it is a desirable area and a more rural option than living in the city centre. It has two non-selective schools with outstanding ratings

📍 Northamptonshire, Wellingborough.

Average 🏠: £239,521

Due to the higher house prices in local villages, property values within a mile of the outstanding Sir Christopher Hatton Academy are slightly less than the local authority average

📍 Southwark, East Dulwich.

Average 🏠: £587,510

On either side of Brenchley Gardens, are Harris Boys’ Academy and Harris Girls’ Academy. See the list of 10 outstanding’ schools here 👇

📍 Northumberland, Morpeth.

Average 🏠: £187,989

Prices are higher than the local authority average in the catchment for the outstanding King Edward VI Academy. The schools, good proximity to Newcastle, the river and parks are all selling points’

📍 Devon, Torquay.

Average 🏠: £233,039

Families head to Lower Ellacombe for better value or the suburb of Babbacombe. This area is a haven of grammar schools, but the local state secondary St Cuthbert Mayne School is rated  good  by Ofsted

❓ Would you move house to live in a better catchment area? 

Let us know 👇

📍 Surrey, Epsom.

Average 🏠: £510,230

Outstanding’ Glyn School and Rosebery School are in the commuter town of Epsom, close to the edge of Greater London. Nearby, Burgh Heath falls under the catchment area for the Beacon School, which is rated  good

📍 Durham, Stockton-on-Tees.

Average 🏠: £155,823

Just 45 minutes from Newcastle, Stockton is well-stocked with green open space with Ropner Park and Preston Park. Some outstanding’ schools include: All Saints Church of England Academy and Egglescliffe School

📍 Cornwall, Charlestown.

Average 🏠: £282,800

The catchment for Penrice Academy in St Austell includes Carlyon Bay and Charlestown. Outstanding schools include Mullion School and the Roseland Academy

Ang Wood, his mother, speaking from her home in Balderton, Nottinghamshire, said:  He called me and said they have no weapons left to fight. I love my son, he is my hero.

Read the full story here 👇

On a social media account administered by a friend, he wrote that he had  no food or ammunition  left and said:
  We tried our best to defend Mariupol, but we have no choice but to surrender to Russian forces. Its been a pleasure, everyone. I hope this war ends soon
A Whitehall source told The Telegraph that the situation in Ukraine made it hard to offer any assistance and said:  We would expect any detainees to be treated in accordance with international law
A pro-Russian social media account posted an image of him with the caption:  Aiden Aslin. Britain, Nottingham. An English mercenary who fought on the side of the Nazis in Mariupol

A Russian soldier wearing a balaclava was seen leading the Briton, known as  Johnny , down a corridor before he was interrogated in what appeared to be an office.

🗣️ Mr Aslin, looking dazed and frightened, said:  I didnt kill anyone
On Russian state television, broadcasters incorrectly described him as a  British mercenary  who had been captured in the shattered city of Mariupol

The Briton enlisted in Ukraines military in 2018 and is therefore owed protection as a prisoner of war. 

🇺🇦 Earlier this year, he revealed that he had bought a house in Ukraine and planned to start a family there with his fiancee
British politicians accused Moscow of breaching the Geneva Convention by using Mr Aslin for propaganda purposes

His mother said she was  in bits  and described him as  my hero

⚡️Scientists have been studying the ageing processes of mammals, from humans to mice and giraffes, and they’ve made a discovery 👇
Read more about the study here 👇
Researchers believe the study opens the door to understanding the ageing process, and the inevitability and timing of death
The average human lifespan in the study was 83.6 years, but the mutation rate was far lower at around 47

🐀It explains how a five-inch long naked mole rat can live for 25 years, about the same as a far larger giraffe, which typically lives for 24. 

When scientists checked their mutation rates, they were  similar.

Naked mole rats suffer 93 mutations a year and giraffes 99

But a new study from the Wellcome Sanger Institute in Cambridge suggests the speed of genetic damage could be the key to survival, with long-living animals successfully slowing down their rate of DNA mutations regardless of their size
➡️Previously experts have suggested that size is the key to longevity, with smaller animals burning up energy more quickly, requiring a faster cell turnover, which causes a speedier decline
🧬Humans and animals die after amassing a similar number of genetic mutations, researchers have found, suggesting the speed of DNA errors is critical in determining the lifespan of a species

Fortunately, for those of us who don’t have a spare few hundred quid to splurge on a health test, Levine has also created a biological age calculator, which anyone can use, at no cost

🗨️ There are billions of these in your genome,  explains Levine.

  Cells have a very specific pattern of these tags. But with ageing, that pattern gets messed up. 

 So we can look at someone and say, Oh, you have a pattern that’s similar to someone who’s 60 years old’

❓But how does the test actually work? 

Its based on something called DNA methylation. 

These are chemical tags that attach to our DNA molecules – they don’t affect the DNA sequence, but they can turn on genes that lead to good health or turn off genes that lead to bad health

🗣️ People are fed up,  says Stuart Lewis, chief executive of Rest Less, an online community for the over 50s.

 Life expectancy estimates have taken a hit. People are very aware of their own health
🟢 The most powerful inducement to return to work wasn’t changes in cost of living, a well-paid job or even a job that better suited their skills – it was for social company’

📈 The ONS figures showed 50-somethings were significantly more likely to give stress or mental health reasons than those aged 60 years and over.

They were more likely to have left for a change in lifestyle or because they did not feel valued in their job

📊 The ONS figures showed that only 15 per cent of them had lost their job. 

The rest chose to leave for other reasons – their job not offering flexible working, not feeling valued, wanting a change in lifestyle, too much stress and simply not wanting to work any more

The largest group to quit their jobs with no intention of finding a new one were professionals and associate professionals – including doctors, scientists, defence staff, people in manufacturing, transport and financial services. 

60 percent  of them hadn’t expected to leave work early

🟢 So, the ONS did something unprecedented.

It asked those over-50s who had reported being out of work a series of questions which all boiled down to one word – why?

The Great Grey Resignation is surprising for two reasons: 

1⃣ It’s a dramatic reversal of the 10 years leading up to the pandemic, when the over-50s were heading into the workplace in ever greater numbers.

2⃣ It isn’t entirely clear why they’re leaving

➡️ Pack now spends more time with his grandchildren 

 It’s tiring – the middle one is one and a half and he’s off like a rocket. It’s good fun. 

 I wouldn’t swap it at all. Financially, I’m no worse off and in my heart I’m much richer

🟢 Graham Pack, 65, left his construction job in March 2021. 

He did the sums and figured if he quit, he’d have some savings and a retirement plan; if he continued working for much longer, he realised,  I’m not going to become Richard Branson
📈 Since the start of the pandemic in March 2020, the number of 50- to 64-year-olds who are neither working nor looking for a job has risen by almost 250,000

➡️For those who cry  balance the books  Lewis shoots back,  we never balance the books . 

States are not like households, he notes, and have far more tools to get round his golden rule of income and expenditure

🔴Chancellor Rishi Sunak should, Lewis says, plug all loopholes to ensure that half of the energy price rise this April is covered, and offer an advance guarantee to do the same ahead of the energy cap being fixed again in October
🗣️It would be another vast state intervention, like furlough,  but we just have to get people through this. There is such anxiety and desperation.
🗣️ This is one of the richest countries in the world. It’s pretty desperate, isn’t it?  Lewis continues

➡️He describes a new feature on the MoneySavingExpert site called  Heat The Human  for those whose homes are now too expensive to warm. 

 I feel slightly sick about doing it. We are talking hot water bottles in sleeping bags territory,  Lewis says
📈Today, he says, rampant inflation affecting food and heating is far outstripping the ability of many people to pay

🗣️Expenditure is shooting uncontrollably past income. 

 For people towards the bottom end, there’s nothing to cut back on. It is not an exaggeration to say that there are people we have to prevent freezing or starving  says Lewis

➡️There is no such dramatic bail out to ease the cost of living crisis and for Lewis, the consequences are clear. 
 I get all these messages from people tearing their hair out. They don’t know how to make things add up

➡️In normal times, Lewis reckons, he can save almost anyone hundreds of pounds a year, simply by ditching unwanted gym memberships, switching to cheaper credit cards, or snapping up a bargain SIM card

🗣️But these days are different.

 The worst since I started,  Lewis says.

 The time I’m most scared for people

From temporary twinges to monumental migraines, here is everything you need to know about easing your pain ⤵️
👁️ Eye strain headaches occur because when you focus on a screen at close range, the muscles in and around your eyes need to work harder, and become sore and tired over time

🟠 Eye strain headaches

Eye strain can trigger both a tension headache and a migraine, but it can also be a form of headache in its own right. 

Eye strain headaches typically appear when you focus on something for a long period of time

🟠 Medication overuse headaches

Rebound headaches are the bane of many regular headache sufferers’ lives, as they occur when someone frequently uses painkillers such as paracetamol, ibuprofen, triptans or opiates for at least three months

Far more common in men, this type of headache tends to occur in a rhythmical fashion at the same time each day. 

➡️ They require specialist treatments to relieve the pain, such as oxygen therapy, sumatriptan injections or nasal spray

🟠 Cluster headaches

A rare type of severe headache, characterised by excruciating pain on one side of the head, often around the eyes. 

 A cluster headache is considered to be one of the most painful conditions known to humans,  says Todd Schwedt, a professor of neurology

🟠 Covid headaches

The data from the Covid Symptoms Study states that headaches are now one of the earliest signs of Covid-19

Covid headaches tend to be a pulsing, pressing or stabbing pain, occurring across both sides of the head rather than just one area

➡️ While they can be treated with common painkillers they can be an indication of dehydration, lack of sleep, emotional stress, dental problems such as jaw clenching or teeth grinding, or too much caffeine

🟠 Tension headaches

These are by far the most common type.

Unlike migraine, they cause a steady, mild to moderate ache rather than a throbbing one and do not tend to come with nausea or sensitivity to light and sound
➡️Common migraine triggers include stress, skipping meals and inadequate sleep, which is why consistency in your daily routine can help reduce the likelihood of attacks

🟠 Migraines

This is characterised as a severe throbbing headache on one side of the head, which can be accompanied by blurred vision, nausea and acute sensitivity to light and sound

🧠Overall there are more than 100 different clinical categories of headaches, ranging from temporary twinges to severe and even life-threatening ones. 

Here is a guide to some of them and their causes, as well as ways of preventing and treating them ⤵️

🤕 If you woke up with a headache this morning, you are far from alone. 

A new study has found that around one in six people worldwide will experience some form of pounding head pain today 

So, whats the cause? ⤵️

🗣️ Sometimes you get so anxious. You are living your whole life in a constant state of heightened [anxiety]  says Phillips

 It peaks and troughs. When things aren’t good, it’s like wallpaper that’s being wrapped around your face to suffocate you. But that’s very rare nowadays

❓How does Jess Phillips cope with the abuse and death threats? 

 I mean, sometimes I don’t.

➡️ Actually, this is a horrible thing to think, but not experiencing people calling you a whore is the thing that isn’t normal. There is no name you could call me that would shock me. It doesn’t reach me, I’m so used to it  says Phillips

⚡ Bellingcat founder Eliot Higgins: Russia lies in the most absurd and grotesque ways’

🔴 These days, it is Russia’s invasion of Ukraine that is consuming Higgins.

🔴 On the morning that we speak, he is busy on Twitter, debunking conspiracist claims that the civilian massacres in Bucha were staged or committed by Ukrainian forces
🔴 Named after an Aesop’s fable in which mice put a bell on a cat’s neck as a warning system, it was Bellingcat that identified the would-be assassins of defector Sergei Skripal in Salisbury

🔴 Initially as a lone blogger on a sofa in Leicester, and from 2014 as the founder of the Bellingcat investigative research agency, he has revealed some of the world’s dirtiest secrets, notably in Russia
🔴 Higgins, 43, is the spiritual father of Open Source Intelligence (Osint) investigations, drawing on freely available information and imagery on the web, much of it posted on social media

🔴 In playing that simple game, father and son are echoing the basic principle on which Higgins has, in the past decade, arguably changed both the overt world of war reporting and the covert world of espionage -- forever
🏅 Over the years, four people have died while playing the game, all by drowning

Households across Britain bought their first TV sets just to watch the occasion, with neighbours crowded in their living rooms

🐶The Queen has owned more than 30 Pembroke corgis and dorgis (a corgi-dachshund cross). 

It is said that if the Queen came in wearing a tiara, they would lie glumly on the carpet; if she was in a headscarf, they knew it was time for a walk

1⃣4⃣Fourteen prime ministers have served the Queen: 10 Conservative and four Labour. 

Winston Churchill – in office when King George VI died – was said to have cried at the news, claiming the new Queen was just a child’

🥬The Queen and Prince Philip had one of the most enduring love stories.

According to royal biographers, Prince Philip called his wife cabbage’, which may have come from mon petit chou’, a French way of saying my darling’. 

In English the term means my little cabbage’

❓And the new Elton? 

Why, it’s Ed Sheeran, of course. 

Critically approved but nakedly populist, he’s projected to become Britain’s first music billionaire.

He’s also solid mates with all of the Sussexes, Cambridges, Eugenie and Beatrice

🎶All the young royals like Ellie Goulding.

The Cambridges had the singer-songwriter, a friend of Princess Eugenie’s, perform at their wedding in 2011. Her set included a cover of Elton’s Your Song.

The Sussexes, not to be outdone, had Elton perform himself.

🎹 William has said he likes Coldplay, AC/DC, Linkin’ Park and Shakira, and once sang Livin’ On A Prayer on stage with Taylor Swift and Jon Bon Jovi.

Kate, who as a pianist is one of the few royals who can actually play an instrument, performed at Westminster Abbey last year

🎵Diana had other showbiz friends, of course.

The urban rumour that she was once whisked off, in disguise, for a night out at the Royal Vauxhall Tavern with Freddie Mercury and Kenny Everett will never die; nor will her dance with John Travolta at the White House in 1985.

🎶It was Andrew who introduced Elton John to Diana, the Princess of Wales, when they were both invited to his 21st birthday party.

 There was no one out there but the dance band and Princess Diana. We danced the Charleston alone on the floor for 20 minutes,  Elton recalled

🎸A notable absentee from any list of Charles’s favourite music is Elton John, but that is perhaps understandable.

Elton and the royals is a complex relationship. 

He was another friend of Margaret’s and sat front row at the wedding of Sarah Ferguson and Prince Andrew in 1986

🎶Other favourites of the Prince – who famously had his bum  patted  by Geri Halliwell when he met the Spice Girls in 1997 –  include Upside Down by Diana Ross, Don’t Rain On My Parade  by Barbra Streisand, and anything by Leonard Cohen

🥁Prince Charles had his musical friendship, too.

US vocal group The Three Degrees performed for his 30th birthday, after which he became firm friends with Sheila Ferguson.

🎵Margaret became friends with Mick Jagger in the 1960s. 

A biographer later claimed they’d had an affair. 

Further scurrilous rumours had it that the Queen refused to personally knight Jagger in 2003, when Tony Blair made him Sir Mick, as she was still angry about it

🎶Princess Margaret was the one who visibly loved that Beatles performance in 1963.

She always was a music fan – and remains the only royal to have appeared on Desert Island Discs. Rock, Rock, Rock by Carl Ravazza nestled between Swan Lake and Cwm Rhondda in her list

🎸If the Beatles wanted to remain anti-establishment, they failed. 

The Queen Mother said she  simply adores them , while even the Duke of Edinburgh called them  good chaps . 

In 2002, Paul McCartney headlined the golden jubilee concert

🥁The Queen has certainly had to watch a lot of musical performances, not least at the Royal Variety Performance.

Next year will mark 60 years since the Beatles irritated some of their fans by playing the ultimate establishment event

🎼 In 2016, a playlist featuring the Queen’s 10 favourite songs was unveiled, which included The Lord Is My Shepherd and Vera Lynn’s The White Cliffs of Dover.

The most recent choice was Sing, by Gary Barlow and the Commonwealth Band featuring the Military Wives choir

🧬The number of deaths globally from this nefarious genetic variant  is in the hundreds of thousands to a million,  Prof Davies said

Read the full story 👇

🗣 Neanderthals  looked just like us,  according to Dr Simon Underdown, a biological anthropologist.

 What would happen when a Neanderthal came into contact with Homo sapiens? Would they even recognise them as different? I would argue very much that they wouldnt,  he said

💬  The reason that we know that is that its inherited as this block with 28 single letter changes,  said Prof Davies 

 You can track that all the way back and it has to be a single event

➡️Dr Davies also revealed that the Neanderthal gene first infiltrated humans 60,000 years ago after one interspecies tryst between a human and a neanderthal.

A solitary coupling event across species lines saw the deadly Covid gene jump from our now-extinct cousin species into us

🔬The Neanderthal gene changes how a cell behaves when the SARS-CoV-2 virus binds to the ACE2 receptor on a human cell.

 What this high risk variant does is it creates a new signal that tells that gene to stay on for slightly too long in response to infection,  Prof Davies said

🗣 This tiny section of DNA doubles your risk of dying from Covid,  said Prof Davies.

 Its position 45,818,159 on chromosome three, and its a single change. 

 If youve got a G at that site, its low risk. And if you have an A at that site it is high risk

🧬The method allowed him to identify LZTFL1 as the culpable gene increasing mortality.

Previous methods had failed to narrow it down beyond 28 different genes

🧪 Dr James Davies of the University of Oxford, a genomic expert and ICU doctor, discovered the innocuous gene’s lethal role last year after creating a brand new cutting-edge way of looking at DNA in exceptional detail

➡️ The LZTFL1 gene is a Neanderthal gene found on chromosome three and has been previously shown to double a person’s risk of severe disease and death.

Roughly 15 per cent of Europeans have the Neanderthal form of the gene, compared to about 60 per cent of South Asians
